title: A Pilot Study to Evaluate the Effect of CT1812 Treatment on Amyloid Beta Oligomer Displacement Into CSF in Subjects With Mild to Moderate Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: This is a multi-center, Phase 1b, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled parallel-group trial in adults with mild to moderate AD.
description_detailed: This is a multi-center, Phase 1b, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled parallel-group trial in adults with mild to moderate AD. The primary endpoint is the change from the baseline CSF Amyloid beta oligomer concentration after dosing with CT1812 versus placebo. The change from baseline will be measured through a number of exploratory endpoints as indicated below. For each subject, the baseline CSF oligomer concentration will be computed as the average of the measurements from hours -4, -3, -2 and -1 and 0.
drug: CT1812 (small-molecule sigma-2/TMEM97 antagonist; a brain-penetrant agent intended to displace Aβ oligomers)
explanation_target: Reason: The study title and description state the intervention is CT1812 and the primary outcome is displacement of amyloid‑beta (Aβ) oligomers into CSF — an on‑pathology biomarker. CT1812 is described in the literature as an orally bioavailable, brain‑penetrant small molecule that modulates the sigma‑2 receptor/TMEM97 and displaces Aβ oligomers from synapses, i.e., it targets AD pathology rather than only symptomatic cognition or neuropsychiatric symptoms. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: Key extracted details — Phase 1b randomized double‑blind placebo‑controlled trial in mild–moderate AD; intervention = CT1812; mechanism = sigma‑2 receptor (S2R/TMEM97) antagonist/allosteric modulator that displaces Aβ oligomers into CSF (target engagement biomarker). These features identify CT1812 as a disease‑targeting small molecule (pathology-directed). citeturn0search0turn0search3

Reflect: Classification check — CT1812 is not a biologic (no monoclonal antibody or vaccine), it is a small molecule with a proposed disease‑modifying mechanism (displacing toxic Aβ oligomers). Therefore the correct category is 'disease‑targeted small molecule'. I reviewed multiple reviews and trial reports that consistently describe CT1812 as a sigma‑2 receptor small molecule antagonist with Aβ oligomer displacement activity. citeturn0search2turn0search4

explanation_agent: Reason: The trial tests CT1812, a brain‑penetrant small molecule that allosterically modulates the sigma‑2 receptor/TMEM97 and is reported to selectively prevent and displace amyloid‑beta (Aβ) oligomers from synapses into CSF — the primary pharmacodynamic outcome is Aβ oligomer displacement, an on‑pathology biomarker. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: Key extracted details — intervention = CT1812 (small‑molecule σ‑2/TMEM97 antagonist/modulator); mechanism = displacing toxic Aβ oligomers from synapses into CSF (target engagement biomarker); phase and design = Phase 1b randomized double‑blind placebo‑controlled (Aβ‑oligomer displacement measured). These facts indicate the intervention is directed at amyloid‑beta oligomers (pathology‑directed), so assign CADRO category A) Amyloid beta. citeturn0search0turn0search3

Multiple reviews and the Phase 1b report support target engagement with Aβ oligomers, so the classification is confirmed. citeturn0search1turn0search2
